programme.title: Mat 1: Women's -63kg, Men's -81kg Repechages/Semi-Finals/Finals | Judo | Olympic Games Paris 2024
programme.desc: The Women's -63kg and Men's -81kg Finals took place on 30/07/2024 at the Champ-de-Mars Arena, Paris. At the Women's -63kg, Andreja Leski (SLO) claimed the Gold medal, Prisca Awiti Alcaraz (MEX) won the Silver, and the Bronze medals went to Laura Fazliu (KOS) and Clarisse Agbegnenou (FRA). At the Men's -81kg,Takanori Nagase (JPN) won the Gold medal, Tato Grigalashvili (GEO) took the Silver, and the Bronze medals went to Somon Makhmadbekov (TJK) and Joonhwan Lee (KOR).

programme.title: Meet the transgender swim star who’s earned a spot on the men’s team
programme.desc: Schuyler Bailar is a decorated swimmer who was recruited to Harvard as a female, but has found peace after transitioning to a male.

programme.title: Memory Lane | 72 - A Gathering of Champions
programme.desc: Fifty years after their Olympic victories in Munich, famed gymnast Olga Korbut, Germany’s long jump star Heide Rosendahl, Kenya’s long-distance running hero Kip Keino and Great Britain’s celebrated pentathlete Mary Peters make an emotional return to the scene of their gold medal wins.

programme.title: Behind the invincibility of South Korea archery
programme.desc: A look at how the winning combination of old traditions and cutting edge training techniques gave South Korea its archery superiority.

programme.title: Kiwi defender who survived it all, ready for World Cup | World at their Feet
programme.desc: Rebekah Stott, who plays for Brighton & Hove Albion in the English FA Women's Super League, is also a veteran of two Olympics and cancer survivor. She was sidelined by her illness and missed Tokyo 2020 but she is now back stronger than ever on New Zealand’s national team and looking forward to an emotional home World Cup as well as becoming a three-time Olympian next summer in Paris.

programme.title: Atletico Madrid's darling is key to Colombia success | World at their Feet
programme.desc: Her parents sacrificed everything to give her a chance to achieve her dream of becoming a professional player. From a farming village in the middle of Colombia to being the best number 10 of her country, Leicy Santos’ story is an amazing journey. She left alone to Bogota at 12 and at 15 years old, she was called into the national team. She participated in Rio 2016 Olympics. After winning the first ever professional women’s championship in 2017 with Santa Fe, in 2019, she was the first ever Colombian Player to be signed for a European team, first Colombian player to score in the Champions League and MVP in 2019/20 for Atletico Madrid. She now targets top 3 at FIFA Women’s World Cup 2023.

programme.title: Brighton keeper from Australia in fourth World Cup | World at their Feet
programme.desc: Lydia Williams grew up in an Aboriginal community in the middle of Western Australia. At 11, she moved to Canberra. Her mum who was from the US signed her up for football. The local club that she joined only had one position left in division one: goalkeeper. She lost her father at 15 and put all her efforts into football. She was 16 when she made her debut for Australia and 19 at her first World Cup. Rio 2016 Olympics was a special moment for her since Cathy Freeman had always inspired her. Having competed in three world cups and two Olympic Games, she has now reached 100 caps, no doubt that this home competition will be very special for her.

programme.title: US Captain determined to give it all to defend title | World at their Feet
programme.desc: Lindsey Horan is one of the first US players to have joined a European club as she decided to skip college and become professional at 18 when joining PSG. The normal path for any US footballer was College and then playing for one of the US teams. She overcame tough times and by the end of her time in PSG she had scored 46 goals in 58 appearances. She left Europe for Portland to achieve her dream of playing at the Olympics in Rio 2016. Winning the 2019 World Cup with the team was definitely a key moment but she sees her Bronze medal in Tokyo 2020 as the highlight of her international career so far.
